title: Saltimbocca alla Romana
description: Classic Roman dish of thin veal cutlets topped with prosciutto and fresh sage, quickly pan-seared and finished in a white wine-butter pan sauce. Bright, savory and herbaceous with a tender texture and a silky reduction that clings to the meat.

ingredients.notes: pounded to 3-4 mm thickness if not pre-sliced
about 15 g per slice, thinly sliced
such as pinot grigio or trebbiano
lightly crushed, optional for pan flavor
adjust to taste; do not oversalt because prosciutto is salty

steps.text: Prepare the veal: pat cutlets dry, trim any fat, and if needed place between plastic and pound to even thickness (3-4 mm). Lightly season the meat on both sides with salt and pepper and dust both sides with a thin coating of flour, shaking off excess.
Assemble: lay a slice of prosciutto over each veal cutlet and press 2 sage leaves onto the prosciutto so they adhere. If desired, secure with a toothpick but not necessary with thin prosciutto.

Heat a large skillet over medium-high heat and add olive oil and half the butter. When the butter foams and oil is shimmering, add the veal cutlets prosciutto-side down. Sear without moving until the prosciutto is crisp and the veal edge begins to brown, about 1.5-2 minutes.
Flip each cutlet and continue to cook the other side until the veal is cooked through but still tender, about 1.5-2 minutes. Remove cooked cutlets to a warm plate and tent with foil to rest briefly.

Lower heat to medium, add the remaining butter and optional crushed garlic to the skillet; saut√© briefly just to scent the pan without burning. Pour in white wine to deglaze, scraping up browned bits with a wooden spoon. Simmer briskly until the wine reduces by about half and becomes slightly syrupy.

Finish the sauce: swirl in lemon juice and whisk in the pan until the butter melts into the reduced wine to create a glossy sauce. Taste and adjust seasoning with a small pinch of salt and pepper if needed.

Return the veal to the pan briefly to warm and coat with sauce, spooning sauce over each piece. Serve immediately, spooning extra pan sauce over the cutlets and garnishing with reserved sage leaves or a lemon wedge.
